subject: ENGRC
description: This .5 credit course brings together students, Cornell faculty, and other distinguished guests for informal, substantive engagement around a wide range of issues and endeavors: intellectual, cultural, artistic, scientific, moral, social, and political.
catalogComments: Enrollment limited to: residents of North Campus student halls and living centers with priority to first-year students. Chaired by Faculty-In-Residence instructors.

subject: ENGRC
titleLong: Project Team Communications: Practicum in Technical Writing

notes.descrlong: For project teams only.

description: The course focuses on the communicative action or work that students are doing as part of their participation in project teams.
catalogSatisfiesReq: Undergraduate students, preferably juniors and/or seniors, that are participating in project teams can fulfill their technical writing requirement by arranging with engineering communications staff to take a one-credit hour ENGRC course in conjunction with their project team participation.

subject: ENGRC
titleLong: Antennas & Radar: Practicum in Technical Writing

subject: ENGRC
titleLong: Writing Intensive Opportunity: Practicum in Technical Writing
description: One-credit attachment to an existing engineering course that is not one of the officially designated W-I courses. It may be taken more than once, with different courses by permission of a particular engineering faculty member.

subject: ENGRC
description: Members of the ECP occasionally give independent (also called "directed") studies in engineering communications, typically with students who are ready for advanced work in technical communication. A student doing a directed study works one-on-one with an ECP instructor to pursue an aspect of professional communications in more depth than is possible in the ECP's regular courses. Various types of projects are possible, e.g., studying forms of technical documentation, creating user manuals, analyzing and producing technical visuals, reading and writing about problems in engineering performance, and communicating about technical topics for the public.

subject: ENGRC
description: ENGRC 3500 in that students write various types of documents (e.g., letters, memos, executive summaries, progress reports), give talks, and incorporate graphics in both their oral and written work. However, ENGRC 3350 focuses on understanding communication within engineering organizations and within student teams. Students work in project teams throughout the semester to write reports and deliver talks. The focus of the project teams depends on instructor, but might include analyzing case studies of engineering organizations, studying organizations on-site, and analyzing concepts in organizational communication and behavior.
catalogComments: May be used as free or approved elective in expressive arts.
catalogPrereqCoreq: Prerequisite: two first-year writing seminars and major affiliation.
catalogSatisfiesReq: Fulfills college technical-writing requirement. This course also fulfills a liberal studies requirement or the Organizational Behavior requirement for ORIE students.
catalogPermission: Enrollment limited to: juniors and seniors.

subject: ENGRC
description: Prepares students for important communication activities. They communicate using various types of documents (e.g., emails, memos, problem analyses, proposals, progress reports), give oral presentations, and incorporate graphics in their oral and written work. Students learn how to communicate specialized information to different audiences (e.g., technical and nontechnical audiences, colleagues and clients, peers and supervisors, and in-house departments), work in teams, and address organizational and ethical issues. The course material is drawn from professional contexts, principally engineering, and it generates lively discussion. The class size ensures close attention to each student's work.
catalogComments: May be used as free or approved elective in expressive arts.
catalogPrereqCoreq: Prerequisite: two first-year writing seminars and affiliation with a major.
catalogSatisfiesReq: Fulfills college technical-writing requirement. This course also fulfills a liberal studies requirement.
catalogPermission: Enrollment limited to: juniors and seniors.

subject: ENGRC

notes.descrlong: For more information go to: http://www.sce.cornell.edu/ws/courses/courses.php?v=2053

subject: ENGRC
titleLong: Communication for Mechanical Engineering Design and Innovation

notes.descrlong: Enrollment is limited.for students co-registered in MAE 2250, Mechanical Synthesis. May be used for liberal studies, CE category, 2000+. For details: https://blogs.cornell.edu/maeugadvising/files/2015/11/ENGRC-2250-S16-28z9tga.pdf

description: This course will provide early preparation for engineering communication tasks and deliverables, reflecting the needs of mechanical and aeronautic engineering (MAE. Course content will cover how to effectively and strategically deploy written work, presentations, technical visuals, and other applicable genres that are useful for MAE work and beyond. Students will be introduced to the concepts and application of how engineering thought, innovation, and design are communicated to various stakeholder audiences.
catalogPrereqCoreq: Prerequisite: one First-Year Writing Seminar or equivalent. Corequisite: MAE 2250.

subject: ENGRC
titleLong: Technical Communication for Applied Engineering Physics

notes.descrlong: Corequisite: AEP 2640.

catalogPrereqCoreq: Corequisite: AEP 2640.

titleLong: Project Team Communications: Practicum in Technical Writing

description: The course is designed to allow students to use their Co-op experience to enhance their appreciation of the importance of professional communication and to facilitate in an authentic professional setting the development of critical communication skills and competencies.

subject: ENGRC

notes.descrlong: This Online Summer Session class is offered by the School of Continuing Education and Summer Sessions. For details visit http://www.sce.cornell.edu/ss/courses/courses.php?v=2053

description: Prepares students for important communication activities. They communicate using various types of documents (e.g., emails, memos, problem analyses, proposals, progress reports), give oral presentations, and incorporate graphics in their oral and written work. Students learn how to communicate specialized information to different audiences (e.g., technical and nontechnical audiences, colleagues and clients, peers and supervisors, and in-house departments), work in teams, and address organizational and ethical issues. The course material is drawn from professional contexts, principally engineering, and it generates lively discussion. The class size ensures close attention to each student's work.

subject: ENGRC

subject: ENGRC
titleLong: Communication for Mechanical Engineering Design and Innovation

notes.descrlong: Enrollment is limited.for students co-registered in MAE 2250, Mechanical Synthesis. May be used for liberal studies, CE category, 2000+. For details: https://blogs.cornell.edu/maeugadvising/files/2015/11/ENGRC-2250-S16-28z9tga.pdf

description: This course will provide early preparation for engineering communication tasks and deliverables, reflecting the needs of mechanical and aeronautic engineering MAE. Course content will cover how to effectively and strategically deploy written work, presentations, technical visuals, and other applicable genres that are useful for MAE work and beyond. Students will be introduced to the concepts and application of how engineering thought, innovation, and design are communicated to various stakeholder audiences.
catalogPrereqCoreq: Prerequisite: one First-Year Writing Seminar or equivalent. Corequisite: MAE 2250.
